oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. John Baptist Church: north facade
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 2401 Carlos Ave SW, Birmingham, Jefferson County, AL

Black and white photograph of a one story brick church with projecting gabled portico on four fluted wood columns. The gable face is wood shingled with a central louvered lunete vent. The central entry is under a broken pediment with flanking pilasters. The porch is approached by eight steps that surround it on three sides. Steeple at the roof gable peak.

St. John Baptist is a large church in the Powderly neighborhood of southwest Birmingham. The first church building was constructed in 1910 and elements of the original building are included in the large expansion built in 1966. An educational building was added in 1973. The church was active during the civil rights era in Birmingham and two of its pastors, Rev. Joseph Crosby and Rev. Ambus Hill, were leaders in the Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights (ACMHR). Mass meetings of the ACMHR were held in the church during 1961 to discuss issues such as the closing of city parks after segregation in the parks was ruled unconstitutional. The activism of the church in the early 1960s is credited in part with the growth of the congregation and the need for a larger sanctuary.
